transcript.content: Placebo, The Bitter End, on Xfm 104.9, I’m Ricky Gervais. With me, is both Stephen Merchant and Karl, the K- Man Pilkington.
So… you’ve already got that, that’s safe it’s only four minutes past. You’ve had Placebo and you’ve got us three, s-so…
You’re definitely going home with that.
That’s safe, that’s – that’s on its way to the hospice.
Yeah. Now, do you wanna gamble all that to go on and listen for another two hours – you could walk away now and you’ve - you’re up.
You have not wasted any time.
Or… do you wanna gamble that against another two hours, it might be shoddy, it might go downhill, but it might get even better Karl, what do you say they do, listen for another two hours?
See, we shouldn’t have done that.
‘Cos a lot of ‘em now are already taking what they’ve got.
And what they’ve got is great, Rick, what they’ve got is lovely.
They’re loving that, they’re gonna enjoy that.
We have got… Monkey News, we’ve got Cheap as Chimps – that’s not the same thing!
How many radio stations have got two ape related, simian features?
Rick, can I point out now a lot of people are making that mistake, a lot of people are thinking that Monkey News is exactly the same as Cheap as Chimps.
It’s not. It’s not. It’s in the same ballpark, but it’s, it’s n… it’s not the same.
There are apes r – that are involved.
They’re involved, yeah yeah yeah yeah yeah. We’ve also got some great music… yeah, we’ve got an amusing sketch about a fly.
Aw, I was looking forward to that.
Ohhhh. And Mystique are dropping in.
Let’s hope the Mystique ladies are coming in.
Singing their new hit for us.

Yeah look, I wanna, I wanna kick off with a song, that is… you know you’ve got like, half a dozen posing songs that when you’re sort of like between fourteen and eighteen, they were the ones you’d put on to get ready to go out, or just posing round or, or be that pop star, or think you’re on stage or whatever, or in the video.
And embarrassingly, I reme… I jus… dug this out and I remembered I used to pose to this like a motherf…er when I was about fourteen, right. This is Street Life, by Roxy Music. You used to do…
Mine was, uhhh… mine was Oops Upside Your Head.
It was just me, on the floor, in me bedroom. One day I thought, one day I thought there’ll be other people in this imaginary pose.
Yeah. But then I remember later, it was Black Lace’s Superman, which is something similar, do you remember that? That was brilliant.
Steve sings the tune to Black Lace Superman.
If you’ve, uh, um, out there in radio land, got any funny – funny jokes, then call in on…
Street Life. Roxy Music, off the Stranded album. That’s what I used to jump around to...
What would you have been wearing while you were listening to that?
Umm. Well, probably, um, Brutus Gold jeans...
Ummmm... aw, uh, Green Flash... uh, pumps.
Uh, oh, I would’ve had socks, yeah.
Um. I’d have probably been wearing the shirt my mum got me from Tescos, which was uh, which was again a Brutus shirt, and, uh, it had women in bikinis eating bananas.
What, lots of small ones? Or just one big one?
Yeah yeah yeah, lots of little small ones yeah, so uh, y’know, uh, uhhhh, so that was that.
A trilby? Have you ever, have you ever toyed with the trilby?

I didn’t wear a trilby, no. I remember when I was, when I, I went on holiday about that time and I was about fourteen and my br... my older brother had this leather jeacket, and I was on the, I was on the beach, um... just, you know, in – in me shorts an’ that. And, uh, I went to get an ice cream or something, and I said ‘can I borrow your jacket’. And, uh, I put his jacket on, and I was cruising on the beach thinking, they are all looking at me.
And I also had a, um, a straw Stetson.
And I really thought... yeah. I’m n – I’m turning into quite a man.
Yeah. Just thinking a little bit, just thinking they’re going, they’re looking, they’re going, who’s that dude? Is he American? Is it, hold on, is he, is he, come from some sort of rodeo?
Wait a minute, I’m in a bikini, and I like bananas.
I could be the woman for him.

What was the... didn’t you have, the - a t-shirt or a jacket or something that you wore to university, that was pretty classy, didn’t it have like, some - some foul language on it or something? What was this?

Uh, yeah, I had, uh, when I was, uh, this was when I was eighteen, right, the Christmas or no, the birthday before I went to, uh, uh, university, I got two sweatshirts, one black, one red, had bullshit on them.
I like, and the red one, all my clothes, the first wash, everything was pink. All my white shirts, all my white socks of course, cos I just put it in there, I didn’t know.
Yeah. So, uh, so, I was a man at university, with all pink clothes except for a rather nice red sweatshirt with bullshit on it. Ohh, so, uh, again, turning into quite a man.
Yes. Quite the man. Was that, was that, pre, or post the time you washed your clothes by getting in the bath, and...

That was pre. That was the second year, when I was in... I had to go in digs, I was in, had to go in halls of residence, so, I had a bath, and you had to sort of like, pay, for a bath, you know, so I thought two birds with one stone, I got in the bath with all my white shirts, cos I was going through a sort of look, you know, wearing a white shirt and tie, that sort of... David Sylvian, sort of...
And, uh, uh, Daz. And I just wriggled around in it.
Washed myself. It’s quite a good exfoliate. Um. So, uh, yeah, I didn’t do it again. Cos it was v – sort of, not good for the skin, Daz.
Quite sore, is it, around the sort of, the more intimate regions?
Yeah yeah yeah yeah yeah yeah yeah yeah. So there you go. Roxy Music and Street Life.
Um... I just was, just was working out time, really, just, we’ve got, we’ve got... well, last week we had a lot of stuff that we didn’t manage to cram in.
So I’m just looking at, we’ve got, we have got Cheap as Chimps coming. Uh, Songs of Phrase.
Oh. We haven’t, we’ve forgotten about that.
Why don’t we kick off with that, so we don’t forget it?
Cheap as Chimps or Songs of Phrase, or the film thing, we didn’t get the film done yesterday.
We’ll do that, in a bit. We’ve also got a new feature, Cheeky Freak of the Week.

Incidentally, I should just point out now that, uh, someone has, uh, Ashley Phillips has e-mailed in, um because obviously with, uh, Songs of Phrase, what Karl does, for those that have not heard it, he takes a phrase that you might hear commonly on the show and then he uses various songs...
You never see an old bloke eating a MAAAAARS baaaar.

And, uh yeah, as I say, he uses different chunks of songs and he makes up that phrase and uh, so he has made some suggestions here, Karl. Uh, cause, he thinks that the more common Karl you’re an idiot, fool etc, perhaps is a little overheard. He’d like to, uh, maybe hear: ‘Karl. Pause. I don’t know where to start.’ Which is a common one from Ricky.

‘Karl, which bit of that do you actually think is true?’ And then there’s the regular dialogue between the three of us. Karl ‘Well you know, it could happen.’ Me ‘Sure, sure.’ Ricky ‘No no no Karl, it could never happen, not now, not ever, you’re an idiot, play a record.’ So maybe some of those you could use...
It’s a lot of... it’s a lot of songs...
Well, will we get, will we get it going then...
This week, we’re uh, do you remember the story about me Auntie, having wind for five minutes?
Your auntie, was it your auntie Nora?
Auntie Nora. Umm, she was on a lot of medication and stuff.
And I think that’s a side effect, that comes with it. So, um, yeah, she had wind for five minutes, so I thought we’d dig that one out. Classic line, uh... Me Auntie Had Wind For Five Minutes.
So I’ve got loads of songs here.
Uhm. Me. Auntie. ‘Ad. Wind. For. Five minu... seven tracks.
Why don’t you – when will you learn?
Okay, so you need to identify, if you can be bothered, the artists?
That’s what we’re after, isn’t it?
M-m-m-my. Auntie. Haaad. Wind. For. Fiiiiive... Minutes.
Alright, we’ll play it a few – play it a few times.
Just remember, as many as you can get.
Cos the winner was probably be, who gets five or something, so don’t worry if you’ve, there’s a couple you can’t get, cos you could still probably win.
M-m-m-my. Auntie. Haaad. Wind. For. Fiiiiive... Minutes.
Can I just, what’s the e-mail address?
It’s, well if they go to xfm.co.uk/ricky, they can just send ‘em through there an’ that.
They can... they can send them through that way. Which of these is the, uh, the prize bag?
Yeah, don’t be getting them mixed up.
That’s, that’s the one is it, Karl?
Alright, so let’s see what hot treats you could win, um. As I get them out, Karl, do you wanna play it once more?
M-m-m-my. Auntie. Haaad. Wind. For. Fiiiiive... Minutes.
I recognize... all of them, except... one.
Right, let me see what we’ve got here.
Uhh, ho ho, once again, Karl, you’ve excelled yourself with an arbitrary collection of DVDs.
Just hanging around. Um again, I’m always interested to know which of our Xfm listeners, um, has tastes as broad as this.
Uh, we’ve got the recent BBC adaptation of the Hound of the Baskervilles.

We’ve got uh, what’s this, is this the, this is um, something involving Air, the band Air, I think it’s a single, at best. Now this is probably worth having, this is the current Flaming Lips album, so you’ve excelled yourself there actually Karl, that’s not bad. An Xfm mouse mat. They’re as...
Hold on, a mouse... you can’t give away, that mouse mat, it’s a piece of foam.
Now I was gonna dismiss the, um, the oddball sci-fi movie K-Pax, featuring Kevin Spacey and Jeff Bridges, but Karl, is it signed by Kevin Spacey?
So win that, and put it on eBay, for four pounds fifty.
Ohhh NO! Karl! Don’t give that, no-one wants that, unless it’s ironic.
Series one and two, on DVD, of popular, Northern based sitcom, Bread.
Buy it, sell it, the games gettin’ ‘ard, cos someone’s dealing you a losing card.
They all had a go, all the actors had a line on that song. Ohh...
Play the clips again, they really wanna win it now.
M-m-m-my. Auntie. Haaad. Wind. For. Fiiiiive... Minutes.
I can’t believe this hasn’t been done before.
Cos most of our ideas have.
Verve. Lucky Man, on Xfm 104.9, Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant and Karl Pilkington.
The e-mails, I should point out, aren’t flooding in. On the competition.
No, but it always takes time when they go through the website.
So they’ll be arriving in a bit.
Do you wanna play it once more, for those that’ve just joined us?
M-m-m-my. Auntie. Haaad. Wind. For. Fiiiiive... Minutes.
My auntie had wind for five minutes.
Name the artists. Rick, I, uh, sometimes, I sometimes um, get off at the tube at, uh Tottenham Court Road if I’m gonna – if I wanna look at the record shops before I come into Xfm.
And I, I always cut through Chinatown.

And every time I come to Chinatown, the same thought always strikes me. I always feel like I want to just gather all the little locals, all the little Chinese fellas, just gather them round, and just go... Guys, in what way is this a town?
This is not... at best, what you’ve got here, is a novelty street.
Yeah. Gerrard Street does not a town make.
No! It’s not a town. You’ve had this little street for about a hundred years.
Just cos you’ve got a little pagoda.
You can’t just call it Chinatown, and claim it’s a town.
If I was them though, and you’d done that, I’d go, I’d go, what, what, what you talking about? It is a town, it is a town, it’s our town.
It is a town. It’s our town, we’ve got all lots of stuff.
Where’s your, where’s your church, where’s your mayor?
We don’t need a... we got a, got a betting shop.
You see, you, all you’ve got here, is restaurants.
That does not a town make.
No, no no no no, got a little supermarket with snacks.
Yeah, yeah. Do you wanna buy a dragon?
Do you want to buy an ornamental dragon?
If I, if I wanted to buy one, this is where I would go.
Do you want to buy a gold dragon?
But it’s sprayed gold. Do you wanna buy that?
And I j... it annoys me, cos when I first came to London, I genuinely though Chinatown was gonna be this amazing... like, you know, like... I mean, what they’ve got there is.
You can do whatever, you’d hear a gong, and...
Every time you went in there, right.
And there’d be rickshaws... and, and people walking on those sort of, wooden shoes.
You know those ones? They’re brilliant they are. Just clomping around in them. But nothing! It’s nothing, it’s just...

It just reminds me of um, have you ever been to any of those sort of museums, you tend to have em up North, where you’ve got like, you sort of sit in a little cart, and it sort of rides you through, kind of, I don’t know, it might be...
Yeah, yeah, yeah and they go... Can I have a, um, half a pound of those sweets, please?
If there was some animatronic men, it would just be an exhibit.
All their concession of it being a hundred years ago is that there’s some scales....
In the shop. And there’s a horse outside.
Yeah. The traditional sounds and smells of old England.
And, and the voiceover going ‘Course there was no television.’
So it’s not, yeah, that’s a good point.
Is that a piece of traditional music?
Is that some official, Chinese music, or is that music that someone in this country wrote? Thinking that it sounded like Chinese music.
I think it was the, uh, what was it, the Vapours, wasn’t it?
Oh, is that what, is that...
Cos it sounds sort of... that’s the music, isn’t it? But are you sure they didn’t take that from some other source?
Yeah, no, it is that, it’s that pentatonic scale isn’t it, what is it called?
It’s the black notes, on the piano.
Right, that’s the one I can play along with Eastenders.
Do you know what I don’t get, with it?
Yeah. Chinatown. Cos I always walk through it on the way to work.
Couple of things annoy me. First of all, I think it’s bad business. Just because, if you’ve got a Chinese restaurant, put it somewhere where there isn’t any others.
Yeah but, it’s also a community, they’re, they’re not just a theme park for – for, for other people.
Well, I ended up, I remember going out one night, with Suzanne and some friends, and you got there, and there’s so much choice, it’s that dilemma of, oh, forget it.
It’s specifically, do you fancy Chinese.
Why didn’t you go to the one with the dead ducks hanging in the window?
Well that’s the other thing as well, it’s like, normally you put your good stuff in the window.
If that’s what’s in the window.
And the other thing that annoys me. Walking through it today. There’s always lard on the floor.
It is, honestly. I’m scared I’m gonna slip over. It’s cos of all the restaurants, and that. But why is it, that’s another point...
Well it’s not, it’s not oozing out of the restaurant.
No, but why is it, why is it?
I don’t know what they do.
Shh, careful. Listen, no, but why is it?
That’s why they used to wear those little wooden shoes.
No, okay, look, we’ve gone too...
No, but the thing is as well, they try and wash it with water. Which doesn’t work with lard, and it’s like oil.
Do you know what I mean, even I know that.
You’d think they’d know, wouldn’t ya?
Anyway. Um... thanks for your thoughts on Chinatown, Karl.
Right, I’m gonna play this thing again, cos it is a bit slow today, the e-mail.
It’s not too hard! There’s just clips of songs. What are the artists, e-mail in.
M-m-m-my. Auntie. Haaad. Wind. For. Fiiiiive... Minutes.
He’s getting annoyed, cos he’s put the work in and no-ones...
Remember. I think Kevin Spacey, uh, and the signed K-Pax DVD is probably the only incentive to try and have a go at that one.
Just think you could win by getting one of them.
Here you are, they’re coming in now.
They’re coming in now, okay. This is Electronic.
Definitely. Do you reckon we’ll get away with it, you see, you’ve worried me now.
My apologies, uh, if you were offended at all by my reference to those little wooden shoes.
So, uh, don’t, we- that’s not gonna help, Rick.
That, uh, that Chinese women, uh, used to wear, I don’t know if they still wear them.
Ohhh, dear. We will, we, we’ve only had, uh, one complaint, haven’t we, with the, we got the, the, from the Sonys that one uh, about, talking about the swan’s penis. But uh, you know...

Thing about complaints is, uh, people complain all the time, it’s whether it’s upheld, cos it goes from authority, and then they have to go ‘oh yeah look, that was, that was in poor taste, or... pre-watershed or, or...
Some of the things you’ve said on TV though, you must have been stung.
I’ve, well see, I’ve, only had, again, I’ve only had one upheld, one serious slap on the wrist, for summat I said, but um...

Well I can gen – yeah. I was talking about – and it was a true story – I was talking about this little old man, who is, who’s um, daughter was taken into a home because he used to um, fry up bacon and rub it round his f – to get the dog to lick them.
Right. And you got a complaint?
What... and that was it, that’s, that’s why you got a complaint?
Well he said it on Songs of Praise.
They said – they said it was in poor taste, I suppose.
You know the most um, you know the biggest complaint ever on TV, the most complaints ever for anything on TV was the showing of The Last Temptation of Christ.
Do you know the second? Here y’are, this is the second worst was, I think Anne Robinson, um, putting the Welsh into Room 101.
What, cos, cos she didn’t like ‘em and that.
She said it slightly more eloquently than that.
I can und – the people or the place?
I think it was the place, and therefore the people.
No well, you know me mam and dad have sort of, uh, moved from Manchester, they’ve retired now in Wales, right.
Look at his FACE! Turning his nose up.

No, but... it... it is pretty, depressing. D’you know what I mean, it’s just one of them places that... oh, it’s like you go back in time an’ that when you go there. I mean, maybe the major cities there, maybe Cardiff is alright.
What, even coming from Manchester it’s like going back in time?
It’s just, uh, it’s like one of them places that, where, it feels like every day’s a Sunday. Do you know what I mean there’s, it’s just depressing, and grey, and slate everywhere and...
Lots of vicars walking around going ‘I’m late.’

Well here y’are, here’s the sort of attitude they have, right. There’s – and this is true, cos me mam and dad live there an’ that, right – and they love it, it’s alright, it’s an healthy place to go when you get older an’ that. But, this, this is why they don’t move on. In Wales.
Well. Could - I’d just like to make another -
Sorry to any Welsh people listening, we’re not saying you don’t move on, Karl is.
Sorry about the little Chinese shoes again as well.
The thing is it’s good that, in a way, they do do that, and they don’t wanta be like, you know, rushing about everywhere, cos, the way London is, isn’t that great either, is it either.

Cos, it’s totally the opposite, ‘ere. So, I’m not, I’m not having a go. It is a bit dull. I think even people who live there will agree with me. Right. But, like, one of the shops that me mam and dad use, right, it’s only a little sort of, village-y type shop, uh, can’t be bothered staying open for hours and hours, right, because there’s not enough people use the shop.
So what you do is, uh, they get used to what you buy and -
They put it in a phone box outside.
They put it in a phone box?
Once he found that out, it was like, brilliant.
But that, how is that a bad thing, that’s brilliant.
Well it’s not, for other people, it is for me dad, cos he’s picking up all sorts of stuff.
He’s not nicking other people’s shopping.
Yeahh, well, it’s not like nicking is it, cos it’s not their’s yet.
OHHHH! And you’ve stitched him up, on radio.
They’re gonna think who’s that guy – whi – who is there in town, with a Manc accent, who hangs around a lot -
Who keeps – who keeps making phone calls.
You’ve stitched him RIGHT up there Karl!
I LOVE that, I LOVE that, that your dad was excited when he found out...
I CAN’T believe, I CAN’T believe that he’s moved there, he’s retired to this little village, where it’s based on trust, and community, and he’s abusing it, he’s using his scaly Manc ways...
(imitating Welsh accent) Bloody ‘ell like, there’s, there’s no bread again.
The cats aren’t getting fed... and your father is just, I can’t, that’s obscene. That’s obscene.
(still in Welsh accent) Ohhh. I think it’s Dai Thief. That fella from Manchester.
I don’t even think they’ve got Sky there yet, have they. They can’t listen, they won’t, they won’t know what’s -
I think you’ve stitched him right up. I hope you have actually, I hope he goes down for it. I hope he’s hounded out of the community like Frankenstein’s monster.
They should get burning torches, go up to his mansion...
Set fire to his, set fire to his cottage.
The Streets - Has It Come to This

Right... listener... I'm talking to you now, um, have you seen these posters around with me and Steve on them, right? It's embarrassing, right. We were mucking around at a photo session and XFM wanted to do some posters. We couldn't be bothered to do it again so we let 'em have this one. Irony comes back to haunt ya and it's looks like I think I'm Simon Temple or summat. And Steve's alright. But WE think that Karl should be in it.
Karl doesn't wanna be in it, but it looks like everyone listens to this show for-for Karl's, basically, innocent stupidity and some great tracks.
They don't listen for us anymore, Steve.
So I think there should be a campaign to get Karl on the poster.
Yeah. Well I should point out that I think XFM are more than happy to have him on the poster.
You don't wanna be on there do you?
There's no, there's no need for me to be on it.
I've got so many emails here as I'm sat during the show reading them. So many emails saying "What does Karl look like? I want pictures of Karl."
Well, if they go to, if they go to xfm.co.uk/ricky, we've got those film bits on there, those video mockups where I'm part of it and you can sort of see it on there.
It's not enough, Karl. People wanna see your face, you're part of the show. You're an intrinsic part of the show.
Yeah. We'll get, we'll get you on the poster.
It'll be too much on a poster, they can only take in so much.
They can only take in so much?
Yeah, it's good with two people.
So what do, what do groups do then?
It's like Ringo Starr is being left off the cover of Sgt. Pepper.
Yeah. Or, or, um, Rutherford doesn't get in a lookin' with Genesis.
Yeah. Also, or, "Sorry Tony Banks you can't be in this one."
Just me and- See, you look like Phil Collins so you've gotta be in there.
I don't, I don't photograph that well either.
You're jokin'. Is it 'cause the shine, you look like a little cue ball? Just shines off the top?
A lot of people, as well, I- you should dispel the myth, a lot of people, for some reason, think that you're fat. A lot of people say to me, "is he fat?"
No, but that's because I haven't got much hair so it looks like me head's big.
No, they haven't even seen you. They just think from listening to the show that you're fat.
That's 'cause you're a Northerner. They think you just eat chips and complain about the weather.
I just think you could answer a lot of people, a lot of your critics.
But then, but then, you see, what I don't like about this world is a lot of people judge people on the way they look.
If, if only more people thought like that Steve.
But Karl, you judge people on the way they look.
Yeah, I know. That's what I mean, but I couldn't with me, could I? 'Cause I don't know what I look like.
If I was listening to me on the radio I wouldn't be able to say, "oh, he's a...", ya know? And slag me off an' that, 'cause I don't know what I look like and I quite like that. D'ya know what I mean?
I don't know what you're talking about.
Just-just believe me, right? I'm right on this one. It's best if you leave it.
Well, we're not gonna leave it. We're gonna get you on the poster.
And mainly after seeing myself on videotape this morning. That's put me off.
Oh, oh, I showed him, um, uh, you know, uh, the "Animals" show I did? The show? I did a video and I did behind the scenes footage and I've got a, uh, you've seen it haven't you?
There's a little bit of Karl on there isn't there?
It's great, he's lovely. He can't believe it. He said "Is it playing slow?" 'Cause he's so slow when I come into the office, he's going "Alright?" It- that's how you talk.
And me head, as well. I look like I'm looking into a spoon.
I just think that if we're willing to-to-to, if Ricky's willing to use his celebrity profile for the sake of the show.
I'm willing to look like, uh, ya know, let's say, a fairly handsome kinda cool customer. I think, at least, the very least, Karl is that you appear on there as well.
Are you worried that you'll look the worst out of all three of us?
Uh... Who am I standing next to?
Am I standing next to Steve? I'm fairly confident.
I like the way it's so predictable. You pull the string 'cause you know what it is.
I know. Oh, what were we talking about before? Oh, I was gonna tell you, yeah. You know the, the most complaints ever, The Last Temptation of Christ?
Well, was it, it was Scorcese wasn't it?

It's Martin Scorcese and I-I bought the film recently, actually, 'cause I was intrigued to see it, but I've not actually watched it. But from what I understand, the reason that it was so outrageous is because it has a whole sequence which shows what it would be like if Jesus had lived his life and not martyred himself on the cross. But lived his life as a human being, part of which is, you know, having sex and, uh, so I think that was chiefly what the outrage was. That it was showing this godly man to be, you know, a human as he was supposedly. 'Cause he was supposed to be human, as well. So, uh, so that's the reason. That's the reason there was complaints there, I don't know, I haven't seen the film,
Do you see him having sex? Yeah.
Although it is an actor, Karl. I just wanna point out.
It's a depiction of Jesus Christ.
It's not the real, it's not the real Robert Powell.
It's an actor playing Robert Powell.
You see sex on films and all that, right? When I was growing up-
No. I'm just, just saying an example of this really.
Right? When I was growing up as a kid and I'd be watching films with me dad, right? He'd really be enjoying a film, right? And then a sex scene would happen.
On film? Or just behind ya?
On film, a sex scene would happen.
Your brother up to his old tricks again.
And he'd get up and go make a cup of tea, right?
Typhoo? That he'd stolen from some sort of telephone box?
And like, even recently he'll, he thinks it ruins a film. D'ya know what I mean? 'Cause there's no need for it to happen is there? Really?
Sometimes it's warranted. If the film itself is fundamentally about-
Yeah. Some films it isn't though. Some films it isn't.
Well, of course. Some films it's arbitrary.
I think the films that, um, him and his dad watched together on Channel 5, um.
Probably like- Is it only on Channel 5 in your house?
Yeah, if you're watching you know, I don't know, late night Friday night, you know-
